(0,11): The tank has 11 gallons before Rosa begins driving.

solution.p: We find the x-intercept by setting y=0 and solving for x to learn that x=8\text{,} so the x-intercept is {\left(8,0\right)}\text{.}
We find the y-intercept by setting x=0 and solving for y to learn that y=30\text{,} so the y-intercept is {\left(0,30\right)}\text{.}

####################################### ### Generated from PreTeXt source ### on 2020-04-03T15:54:15-07:00 ### ### https://pretextbook.org ### ####################################### ## DBsubject() ## DBchapter() ## DBsection() ## Level() ## KEYWORDS() ## TitleText1() ## EditionText1() ## AuthorText1() ## Section1(not reported) ## Problem1(1.2.13) ## Author() ## Institution() ## Language(en-US)
DOCUMENT();
############################################################ # Load Macros ############################################################ loadMacros( "PGstandard.pl", "MathObjects.pl", "PGML.pl", "AnswerFormatHelp.pl", "PGcourse.pl", );
############################################################ # Header ############################################################ COMMENT('Authored in PreTeXt PreTeXt'); TEXT(beginproblem());
############################################################ # PG Setup Code ############################################################ Context("Point"); $x0=8; $y0=30; $xint = Point($x0,0); $yint = Point(0,$y0);
############################################################ # Body ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML Find the [`x`]\- and [`y`]-intercepts of the equation in Practice 3 (Notebook[$NBSP]*1.2.10), and use the intercepts to graph the equation. Enter each intercept as an ordered pair.
The [`x`]-intercept is [_]{$xint}{4}.
The [`y`]-intercept is [_]{$yint}{4}.
END_PGML
############################################################ # Hint ############################################################ #Set value of $showHint in PGcourse.pl for course-wide attempt threshhold for revealing hints
BEGIN_PGML_HINT Choose convenient scales for the [`x`]\- and [`y`]-axes.
END_PGML_HINT
############################################################ # Solution ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML_SOLUTION We find the [`x`]-intercept by setting [`y=0`] and solving for [`x`] to learn that [`x=[$x0]\text{,}`] so the [`x`]-intercept is [`[$xint]\text{.}`]
We find the [`y`]-intercept by setting [`x=0`] and solving for [`y`] to learn that [`y=[$y0]\text{,}`] so the [`y`]-intercept is [`[$yint]\text{.}`]
A graph is below.
END_PGML_SOLUTION
############################################################ # End Problem ############################################################
ENDDOCUMENT();

####################################### ### Generated from PreTeXt source ### on 2020-04-03T15:54:15-07:00 ### ### https://pretextbook.org ### ####################################### ## DBsubject() ## DBchapter() ## DBsection() ## Level() ## KEYWORDS() ## TitleText1() ## EditionText1() ## AuthorText1() ## Section1(not reported) ## Problem1(1.3.22) ## Author() ## Institution() ## Language(en-US)
DOCUMENT();
############################################################ # Load Macros ############################################################ loadMacros( "PGstandard.pl", "MathObjects.pl", "PGML.pl", "niceTables.pl", "AnswerFormatHelp.pl", "PGcourse.pl", );
############################################################ # Header ############################################################ COMMENT('Authored in PreTeXt PreTeXt'); TEXT(beginproblem());
############################################################ # PG Setup Code ############################################################ Context("Point"); $answer = Point("(-2.5,-122)");
############################################################ # Body ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML a. Graph the equation [`y=32x-42`] in the window:
[@DataTable( [ [[PGML('Xmin[`=-4.7 \qquad`]'),], [PGML('Xmax[`=4.7 \qquad`]'),], [PGML('Xscl[`=1 \qquad`]'),], ], [[PGML('Ymin[`=-250 \qquad`]'),], [PGML('Ymax[`=50 \qquad`]'),], [PGML('Yscl[`=25 \qquad`]'),], ], ], align => 'lll', center => 0, );@]*
a. Use the Trace feature to find the point that has [`y`]-coordinate [`-122\text{.}`]
[_]{$answer}{8} Enter an ordered pair.
a. Verify your answer algebraically by substituting your [`x`]-value into the equation.
END_PGML
############################################################ # Solution ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML_SOLUTION a. A graph is below.
a. [`(-2.5,-122) `]
a. [`\newcommand\degree[0]{^{\circ}}\newcommand\Ccancel[2][black]{\renewcommand\CancelColor{\color{#1}}\cancel{#2}}\newcommand{\alert}[1]{\boldsymbol{\color{magenta}{#1}}}\newcommand{\blert}[1]{\color{blue}{#1}}\blert{-122} = 32(\alert{-2.5}) - 42`]
END_PGML_SOLUTION
############################################################ # End Problem ############################################################
ENDDOCUMENT();

statement.p:
In 1991, there were 64.6 burglaries per 1000 households in the United States. The number of burglaries reported annually declined at a roughly constant rate over the next decade, and in 2001 there were 28.7 burglaries per 1000 households. (Source: U.S. Department of Justice)
Sketch a line that goes through the two points (t, B) given in the problem, where t = 0 in 1990.
Choose the correct graph.
Find the slope of the line, including units.
m is
What does the slope tell us about this problem?
(in the years 1991 to 2001).

li.p: Because t=0 corresponds to 1990, we have the two points (1,64.6) and (11,28.7). The line joining those two points corresponds to the line with equation y =

We use the two points (1,64.6) and (11,28.7) to compute the slope: -3.59 burglaries per 1000 households per year. From 1991 to 2001, the burglary rate declined by 3.59 burglaries per 1000 households every year.

statement.p:
In 1991, there were 64.6 burglaries per 1000 households in the United States. The number of burglaries reported annually declined at a roughly constant rate over the next decade, and in 2001 there were 28.7 burglaries per 1000 households. (Source: U.S. Department of Justice)
Sketch a line that goes through the two points (t, B) given in the problem, where t = 0 in 1990.
Choose the correct graph.
(A)
(B)
(C)
(D)
Find the slope of the line, including units.
m is
?
burglaries per decade
burglaries per 1000 households per year
households per burglary per year
burglaries per year
What does the slope tell us about this problem?
The burglary rate declined by 3.59 burglaries per decade
The burglary rate declined by 3.59 burglaries per 1000 households every year
The burglary rate declined by 3.59 burglaries per year
(in the years 1991 to 2001).

li.p: Because t=0 corresponds to 1990, we have the two points (1,64.6) and (11,28.7). The line joining those two points corresponds to the line with equation y = {68.19-3.59t}

We use the two points (1,64.6) and (11,28.7) to compute the slope: -3.59 burglaries per 1000 households per year. From 1991 to 2001, the burglary rate declined by 3.59 burglaries per 1000 households every year.

statement.p:
The fee for registering a new car is given by a linear equation that depends on the cars value. The fee for a $15,000 car is $128.50, and the fee for a $25,000 car is $193.50.
Find a linear equation that gives the registration fee F for a new car that cost V dollars.
Answer:
Use your equation to estimate the registration fee for a car that costs $22,000.
$
What is the slope of your line? What does the slope mean in this situation?
The slope is and it tells
the steepness of the car's value.
the fraction of the car's value that is added into the registration fee.
the intest rate of the loan.
how much the car's value decreases.

li.p: 0.0065\text{:} The registration fee increases by 0.65% of the value of the car.

Use the point-slope formula with the first and last data points.
The regression line must pass through two data points, and we use the point-slope formula for those points.
Choose two points on the regression line and use the point-slope formula.

solution.p: Choose two points on the regression line and use the point-slope formula.

statement.p: The regression line in the Example above appears to pass through the points (5, 1.25) and (25, 3.35). Use those points to find an equation for the regression line.

A scatterplot is a type of linear model.
A regression line should give the same y-values as the data points.
We use interpolation to estimate the y-value at a data point.
Extrapolation is usually more reliable than interpolation.

li.p: Use your regression equation from the previous Example to predict the number of cups of cocoa sold when the temperature is -10^\circ\text{C} .

Which prediction is more likely to be accurate? Why?

Predict the number of cups of cocoa sold when the temperature is 7^\circ\text{C}\text{.}

Identify the system as dependent, inconsistent, or consistent and independent.
Inconsistent: The graph consists of parallel lines.
by hand, using either the intercept method or the slope-intercept method.

Inconsistent: The graph consists of parallel lines.

statement.p:
The Aquarius jewelry company determines that each production run to manufacture a pendant involves an initial setup cost of $200 and $4 for each pendant produced. The pendants sell for $12 each.
Express the cost C of production in terms of the number x of pendants produced.
C=
Express the revenue R in terms of the number x of pendants sold.
R=
Graph the revenue and cost on the same set of axes. (Find the intercepts of each equation to help you choose a window for the graph.) State the solution of the system.
Solution Give the solution as an ordered pair.
How many pendants must be sold for the Aquarius company to break even on a particular production run?
The must sell pendants to break even.

li.p: They must sell 25 pendants in order to break even.

statement.p:
Follow the suggested steps to solve the system by substitution: 3y-2x\amp=3x-2y\amp=-2
Step 1
Solve the second equation for x in terms of y.
x=
Step 2
Substitute your expression for x into the first equation.
3y -2 \large({\large)} =3
Step 3
Solve the equation you got in Step 2.
y=
Step 4
You now have the solution value for y. Substitute that value into your result from Step 1 to find the solution value for x.
x=
As always, you should check that your solution values satisfy both equations in the system.
The solution to the system is (Give the solution as an ordered pair.)

li.p: Solve the second equation for x in terms of y\text{.}
Substitute your expression for x into the first equation.
Solve the equation you got in Step 2.
You now have the solution value for y\text{.} Substitute that value into your result from Step 1 to find the solution value for x\text{.}
As always, you should check that your solution values satisfy both equations in the system.
The solution to the system is (Give the solution as an ordered pair.)

[_]{$lhs0}{2}[`=`][_]{$rhs0}{5},
and the second equation by 3.
[_]{$lhs1}{5}[`=`][_]{$rhs1}{3}

* Step 2

Add the new equations and solve the result for [`x\text{.}`]
[`x=`][_]{$x}{2}

Substitute your value for [`x`] into the second equation and solve for [`y\text{.}`]
[`y=`][_]{$y}{2}

END_PGML

############################################################ # End Problem ############################################################

li.p: The method for solving a 3 \times 3 linear system is called .
A special case of this method is called .
The special case works on systems
To reduce a system to the special form, we use .
when one equation involves exactly one variable, and a second equation involves that same variable and just one other variable

?
completing the square
Gaussian reduction
induction method
.

A special case of this method is called
?
back-substitution
negative reciprocals
linear regression
point-slope
.
The special case works on systems

when one equation involves exactly one variable, and a second equation involves that same variable and just one other variable
with more equations than unknowns
having only two unknowns
.

?
guess-and-check
linear combinations
the discriminant

####################################### ### Generated from PreTeXt source ### on 2020-04-03T15:54:16-07:00 ### ### https://pretextbook.org ### ####################################### ## DBsubject() ## DBchapter() ## DBsection() ## Level() ## KEYWORDS() ## TitleText1() ## EditionText1() ## AuthorText1() ## Section1(not reported) ## Problem1(2.4.4) ## Author() ## Institution() ## Language(en-US)
DOCUMENT();
############################################################ # Load Macros ############################################################ loadMacros( "PGstandard.pl", "MathObjects.pl", "PGML.pl", "AnswerFormatHelp.pl", "parserPopUp.pl", "parserRadioButtons.pl", "PGcourse.pl", );
############################################################ # Header ############################################################ COMMENT('Authored in PreTeXt PreTeXt'); TEXT(beginproblem());
############################################################ # PG Setup Code ############################################################ Context('Numeric'); $method = PopUp( ["?", "completing the square", "Gaussian reduction", "induction method"], 2, ); $case = PopUp( ["?","back-substitution", "negative reciprocals", "linear regression", "point-slope"], 1, ); $work = RadioButtons( ["when one equation involves exactly one variable, and a second equation involves that same variable and just one other variable","with more equations than unknowns", "having only two unknowns"], 0, ); $reduce = PopUp( ["?","guess-and-check", " linear combinations", "the discriminant"], 2, );
############################################################ # Body ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML a. The method for solving a [`3 \times 3`] linear system is called [_]{$method}{5}.
a. A special case of this method is called [_]{$case}{5}.
a. The special case works on systems
[_]{$work}{5}.
a. To reduce a system to the special form, we use [_]{$reduce}{5}.
END_PGML
############################################################ # Solution ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML_SOLUTION a. Gaussian reduction
a. back-substitution
a. when one equation involves exactly one variable, and a second equation involves that same variable and just one other variable
a. linear combinations
END_PGML_SOLUTION
############################################################ # End Problem ############################################################
ENDDOCUMENT();

statement.p:
Use Gaussian reduction to solve the system x-2y+z \amp= -1\qquad\qquad \amp\amp (1)\frac{2}{3}x +\frac{1}{3}y - z \amp= -1 \amp\amp (2)3+3y-2z \amp= 10 \amp\amp (3) Follow the steps:
Step 1: Clear the fractions from Equation (2).
Step 2: Eliminate z from Equations (1) and (2).
Step 3: Eliminate z from Equations (1) and (3).
Step 4: Eliminate x from your new 2\times 2 system.
Step 5: Form a triangular system and solve by back-substitution.

instructions.p: Give the solution as an ordered triple.

statement.p: Use Gaussian reduction to solve the system

Follow the steps:
Step 1: Clear the fractions from Equation (2).
Step 2: Eliminate z from Equations (1) and (2).
Step 3: Eliminate z from Equations (1) and (3).
Step 4: Eliminate x from your new 2\times 2 system.
Step 5: Form a triangular system and solve by back-substitution.
Give the solution as an ordered triple.

webwork-reps.pg:
####################################### ### Generated from PreTeXt source ### on 2020-04-03T15:54:16-07:00 ### ### https://pretextbook.org ### ####################################### ## DBsubject() ## DBchapter() ## DBsection() ## Level() ## KEYWORDS() ## TitleText1() ## EditionText1() ## AuthorText1() ## Section1(not reported) ## Problem1(2.4.7) ## Author() ## Institution() ## Language(en-US)
DOCUMENT();
############################################################ # Load Macros ############################################################ loadMacros( "PGstandard.pl", "MathObjects.pl", "PGML.pl", "AnswerFormatHelp.pl", "PGcourse.pl", );
############################################################ # Header ############################################################ COMMENT('Authored in PreTeXt PreTeXt'); TEXT(beginproblem());
############################################################ # PG Setup Code ############################################################ Context("Point"); $triple = Point(2,2,1);
############################################################ # Body ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML Use Gaussian reduction to solve the system
[```\newcommand{\amp}{&}\begin{aligned} x-2y+z \amp= -1\qquad\qquad \amp\amp (1)\\ \frac{2}{3}x +\frac{1}{3}y - z \amp= -1 \amp\amp (2)\\ 3+3y-2z \amp= 10 \amp\amp (3) \end{aligned}```]
Follow the steps: * Step 1: Clear the fractions from Equation (2).
* Step 2: Eliminate [`z`] from Equations (1) and (2).
* Step 3: Eliminate [`z`] from Equations (1) and (3).
* Step 4: Eliminate [`x`] from your new [`2\times 2`] system.
* Step 5: Form a triangular system and solve by back-substitution.
[_]{$triple}{6} Give the solution as an ordered triple.
END_PGML
############################################################ # Solution ############################################################
BEGIN_PGML_SOLUTION [`[$triple] `]
END_PGML_SOLUTION
############################################################ # End Problem ############################################################
ENDDOCUMENT();

authored.pg-code: $explain = RadioButtons( ["Inconsistent", "Dependent", "Consistent and independent"], 0, );

statement.p: Decide whether the system is inconsistent, dependent, or consistent andindependent. x+3y-z\amp=4-2x-6y+2z\amp=4x+2y-z\amp=3
Decide whether the system is inconsistent, dependent, or consistent andindependent.

True or false.
If a system is dependent, it has no solutions.
The equation 0x + 0y + 0z = 0 has no solution
If a 3 \times 3 system is dependent, all three equations are the same..
Gaussian elimination will reveal whether a system is dependent or inconsistent.

statement.p:
Which solutions are exact values, and which are approximations?
x^2=40, \qquad\qquad x=\pm 6.32455532
t^2=\dfrac{81}{64}, \qquad\qquad t=\pm 1.125
w^2=50, \qquad\qquad w=\pm 5\sqrt{2}
b^2=(0.632)^2, \qquad b=\pm 0.632

solution.p: Only the solutions to (a) are approximations.

statement.p: Solve by extracting roots \quad\dfrac{3x^2-8}{4} = 10

statement.p: The glass pyramid at the Louvre in Paris has a square base, is 21.64 meters tall, and encloses a volume of 9049.68 cubic meters. Use the formula ~ V=\dfrac{1}{3}s^2h~ to find the length of the base. Round your answer to hundredths.
Answer: meters

The glass pyramid at the Louvre in Paris has a square base, is 21.64 meters tall, and encloses a volume of 9049.68 cubic meters. Use the formula ~ V=\dfrac{1}{3}s^2h~ to find the length of the base. Round your answer to hundredths.
Answer: meters

statement.p: Find the intercepts of the graph of y=-9-\dfrac{3}{2}x \text{.} Enter each intercept as an ordered pair.
The x-intercept is .
The y-intercept is .

solution.p: We find the x-intercept by setting y=0 and solving for x to learn that x=-6\text{,} so the x-intercept is {\left(-6,0\right)}\text{.}
We find the y-intercept by setting x=0 and solving for y to learn that y=-9\text{,} so the y-intercept is {\left(0,-9\right)}\text{.}
